info.name: ToDo Api Documantaion
info.description:
### Collection Overview:

The ToDo API is a comprehensive RESTful service designed to streamline task management for users. This API supports a full range of task-related operations, including user authentication, task creation, retrieval, updating, and deletion. It’s specifically crafted for developers who want to seamlessly integrate a robust task management system into their applications. With a focus on simplicity and efficiency, the ToDo API provides the essential tools needed to help users stay organized and productive.

### User Component:

The User component of the ToDo API focuses on the essential aspects of user authentication and session management. This component includes key endpoints that allow users to securely authenticate and interact with the API.

- **API Token (POST)**: This is a critical endpoint that should be executed first when using the API. By providing their email, password, and device name, users can obtain an API token. This token is essential for authenticating all subsequent API requests. It is strongly recommended that users save this token and input it into the main documentation as a Bearer Token. This will ensure that the token is automatically included in the headers of all future requests, streamlining the authentication process and securing access to the API’s functionality.
    

### Tasks Component:

The Tasks component is central to the ToDo API, providing a suite of endpoints for comprehensive task management. Whether users need to create new tasks, update existing ones, or simply retrieve a list of their tasks, this component offers the necessary functionality.

- **Get all tasks (GET)**: This endpoint returns a list of all tasks associated with the authenticated user. It also supports optional filtering based on workspaces, allowing users to focus on specific groups of tasks relevant to a particular project or context.
    
- **Get a task (GET)**: With this endpoint, users can retrieve detailed information about a specific task by providing its unique ID. This feature is particularly useful for viewing the full details of a task, such as its status, priority, and associated metadata, which aids in task tracking and management.
    

### Introduction:

The ToDo API is designed with simplicity and usability in mind, offering clear and well-documented endpoints that facilitate easy integration into a wide range of applications. Whether you're developing a small personal project or a large-scale enterprise application, this API provides the necessary tools for managing tasks effectively. The documentation is comprehensive, covering critical aspects such as authentication protocols, error handling, and rate limits, ensuring that developers have all the information they need to implement the API smoothly. By using the ToDo API, developers can create powerful task management solutions that are both flexible and reliable, empowering users to manage their tasks with confidence.

These enhanced descriptions offer a detailed overview of your API’s structure and functionality, adding depth and clarity to each component. You can further expand these sections with specific examples, error messages, and use cases to create a fully comprehensive API documentation.

item.name: User

request.description:
**User Component:**

The User component of the ToDo API is crucial as it handles user authentication and session management, which are foundational for secure interaction with the API.

• **API Token (POST)**: This is a critical endpoint that should be executed first when using the API. By providing their email, password, and device name, users can obtain an API token. This token is essential for authenticating all subsequent API requests. It is strongly recommended that users save this token and input it into the main documentation as a Bearer Token. This will ensure that the token is automatically included in the headers of all future requests, streamlining the authentication process and securing access to the API’s functionality.

item.name: Tasks

request.description: Gets all of your [collections](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/collections). The response includes all of your subscribed collections.

query.description: Optional. A collection's read-only access key. Using this query parameter does not require an API key to call the endpoint.

request.description: Gets information about a collection. For a complete list of this endpoint's possible values, use the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json).

response.name: Successful Response
Get Collection with Access Token
Not Found

body.raw:
{
    "name": "Task 2 - Api Example",
    "description": "In publishing and graphic design, Lorem ipsum is a placeholder text commonly used to demonstrate the visual form of a document or a typeface without relying on meaningful content. ",
    "priority": "P1",
    "due_date": "2025-01-01",
    "user_id": "1",
    "label_id": "11",
    "parent_id": null
}

request.description:
Creates a collection using the [Postman Collection v2 schema format](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/docs/index.html). Include a `collection` object in the request body that contains the following required properties:

- `info` — An **object** that contains the following properties:
    - `name` — A **string** value that contains the collection's name.
        
    - `schema` — A **string** that contains a URL to the collection's schema. For example, the `https://schema.getpostman.com/collection/v1` URL.
        
- `item` — An **object** that contains the HTTP request and response information.
    - `request` — An **object** that contains the collection's request information. For a complete list of values, refer to the `definitions.request` entry in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json). If you pass an empty object for this value, the system defaults to an untitled GET request.
        

**Note:**

- For a complete list of available property values for this endpoint, use the following references available in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json):
    - `info` object — Use the `definitions.info` entry.
        
    - `item` object — Use the `definitions.items` entry.
        
- For all other possible values, refer to the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json).

query.description:
Optional. A workspace ID in which to create the collection.

If you do not include this query parameter, the system creates the collection in your "My Workspace" workspace.

Optional. A workspace ID in which to create the collection.

If you do not include this query parameter, the system creates the collection in your "My Workspace" workspace.

request.description:
Updates a collection using the [Postman Collection v2 schema format](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/docs/index.html). Include a `collection` object in the request body that contains the following required properties:

- `info` — An **object** that contains the following properties:
    - `name` — A **string** value that contains the collection's name.
    - `schema` — A **string** that contains a URL to the collection's schema. For example, the `https://schema.getpostman.com/collection/v1` URL.
- `item` — An **object** that contains the HTTP request and response information.
    - `request` — An **object** that contains the collection's request information. For a complete list of values, refer to the `definitions.request` entry in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json). If you pass an empty object for this value, the system defaults to an untitled GET request.

**Note:**

- For a complete list of available property values for this endpoint, use the following references available in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json):
    - `info` object — Use the `definitions.info` entry.
    - `item` object — Use the `definitions.items` entry.
- For all other possible values, refer to the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json).
    

### Important

Use caution when using this endpoint. The system will replace the existing collection with the values passed in the request body.

Malformed Request
Collection ID Mismatch
